Haywood has a sly smile on his fac As Vaughn comes to his stretch, the convict goes back int his act. He's in jail now, struggling against the bars.  Finally he bends over and grabs his ankles, while one of teammates humps up against him, pretending to bugger him. This sends the Yankee bench into hysterics. Vaughn has lost it now. He fires to the plate and Haywood creams another tape measure job into the upper deck. Haye doesn't even bother to run back to the wall. He just watc it go. 6-0 Yankees.
I thought now that Vaughn had some  control, he was ready for the Yankees.
Not quite yet.
Brown makes his way to the mound to take Vaughn out.
So, Vaughn pitches in some tough  luck here as the Yankees put together  as few squib hits and take a 6-0  lead.
in the press box. The stadium below is empty, the grounds crew covering the infield.

Well, the Indians made a gallant  comeback today, but fell one run  short as the Yankees held on for a 6- 5 victory, although they didn't do  squat after the first inning. Anyway,  if the bus makes it here from the  hotel we'll be on at 7:30 tomorrow  night. Till then, this is Harry Doyle,  saying so long, everybody, and Happy  Hunting.
Brown is alone in the bar having a drink. A figure sits d on the stool next to him. It's Donovan.
Mind if I join you?
(surprised to see him) Donovan. Hell no. What are you doin'  here?
Just wanted to get out on the road.  You damn near pulled one out today.
Someday we'll figure out how to beat  those guys.
Ya know, you've done a helluva job  this year.
Sixty and sixty-one is hardly a  helluva job.
With this club it is.

Ya know, when I first got to camp I  figured this team had no chance. I  was just hopin' we'd win enough that  I could stay on and really start to  build something here. But there's a  lotta talent on this club, Charlie.  The veterans are starting to play  back to form and the rookies are  developing faster than I thought.  There's two or three potential all- stars in there. I think we're a first  division team right now.
You really believe that, don't you?
I know it. All we need is something  to bring it all together.
Rachel Phelps would never allow that.
What do you mean?
She doesn't want you in the first  division. She doesn't even want you  in Cleveland.
On Brown's incredulous face, we...
The players are all gathered around, obviously having bee called together by Brown.

(addressing the group) I got somethin' I think you oughta  know about. I wouldn't have known  about it myself if Charlie Donovan  hadn't told me, although I shoulda  guessed it from everything that's  happened. It seems that Mrs. Phelps  doesn't think too highly of our worth.
We take several CUTS OF FACES around the room.

She put this team together because  she thought we'd be bad enough to  finish dead last, knockin' attendance  down to the point where she could  move the team to Miami. (pause) And get rid of all of us for better  personnel.
Taylor, Vaughn, Hayes, Dorn, and the others can hardly be what they're hearing.
Even me?
Even you, Dorn.
Silence descends on the room.
In other words, Phelps thinks we're  all dinks. That we don't belong in  the big leagues.
That's about it.
What if we don't finish last?
She'll replace you with somebody who  will. After this season, you'll all  be sent back to the minors or given  your outright release. (pause) So, all we're gonna get is this one  year.
Taylor surveys the bowed heads around the room. He stands address the group.

I don't know about the rest of you,  but I've been playin' baseball since  I was five years old. I've had some  good years and some years to forget.  I've burned out my knees... I don't  think I have three fingers that work  right... I've lost most of the money  I made and baseball has messed up my  personal life from time to time. But  I know one thing... I can still play  this game a little. And I'd like to  know who in this room thinks they're  the kinda bum Mrs. Phelps is lookin'  for?
Eyes dart around the room, then come back to Taylor. No h are raised...
Well, then, I guess there's only one  thing to do.
What's that?
Win the whole fuckin' thing.
We take CUTS of the startled faces of the players. As the idea sinks in, they begin to come to life. MUSIC begins a we're into a...
detailing the newly-motivated Indians' drive for the penn and the "Pennant Fever" it creates in Cleveland. We begin with...

hanging a full size blowup of Rachel Phelps on the locker room wall. In the picture she's pointing as if out at the players, and a bubble above her head says, "YOU GUYS STIN A set of designer clothes, of the type Rachel wears, have been superimposed on the picture. The clothes are divided into 32 pull-off squares.
I figure it's gonna take 32 more  victories to win this thing. Every  time we win, we peel a square.
coming out of an elevator in the Turk, with a wheelbarrow full of dirt. We pan him down the hall, where we see a di sliding area he's been building up.

leading off a makeshift base in the hall of the Turk. As  Vaughn tosses a ball up in the air, Hayes takes off down hall toward another base on the dirt sliding area. Vaughn catches the ball and rifles a throw down to Taylor who puts the tag on the sliding Hayes. Cerrano, who's ump calls Hayes out. Hayes jumps up and argues vociferously,  hopping around in frustration.
Sequence omitted from original script.
hitting one rocket-shot ground ball after another at Dorn Some bounce off his chest and arms, but Dorn stays in fro of every one.
taking off his shirt in the locker room. His chest is a m of welts and bruises.
"polishing" his bats with black shoe polish and a brush.
taking batting practice late at night. He attacks the bal swing after swing.
Sequence omitted from original script.

taking his stretch with a man on first, and firing to the plate. The Batter swings and misses for strike three, whi the Runner on first breaks for second. TAYLOR rifles a th down to second nailing the Runner for a double play.
taking a hot smash off his chest. He picks it up and guns the runner down.
Sequence omitted from original script.
stealing home, as the opposing Pitcher tries frantically hurry his windup. Hayes slides across safely, hooking to infield side. He jumps up and punches the air with his fi
nailing up the pair of black gloves he used to steal home above his bed.

head_text.subj: "INDIANS WIN FIFTH STRAIGHT, CRACK FIRST DIVISION"

text: Ross Farmer, microphone in hand, stands in front of a bla bonfire. A large crowd cheers as various people throw doo on the blaze.
(to TV camera) You remember bra burning in the '70's,  well, the newest thing in Cleveland  is doormat burning as Indian fans  are standing up and saying "We won't  be stepped on anymore".
blowing fast balls by hitter.
with Donovan next to her, watching all this good play in  disgust.

lining a single to center. Cerrano charges it and fires t the plate as a Runner tries to score from second. Just as Taylor catches the ball, he's once again knocked flat by Runner. This time he lies still a beat, and then an arm c up holding the ball. The Umpire thumbs the Runner out.
late at night, sitting head-down in the outboard motor  whirlpool. He's hurting.

We PICK UP three Teenage Girls walking down the street we T-shirts that say WILD THING--I THINK I LOVE YOU. A Black Kid comes by wearing black gloves on each hand. As he pas he holds up one finger signifying Number One. The Girls r the signal.

The Business Executive passes his secretary's desk, gives her some instructions, and goes into his office. As soon he's out of sight, she opens her drawer and slips the ear from a portable radio into her ear. OVER, we hear the Ind BROADCAST.
inside his office. He opens his desk drawer and pulls out earplug. He's also listening to the game.
Sequence omitted from original script.
Sequence omitted from original script.
The Stripper is wearing a squaw costume, with black glove and a WILD THING T-shirt. Several members of the audience have radio earplugs on.
of squares of leopard skin fabric being peeled away. Unde one is revealed a section of bare hip and thigh. Under  another, a navel. Under still another, the edge of a bare breast and arm.
all dressed in tuxedos, posed "team picture" style on the infield of Municipal Stadium.
(in unison) Hello, do you know us?
We're a Major League baseball team,  but since we haven't won a pennant  in thirty years, nobody recognizes  us, not even in our own hometown.
That's why we carry the American  Express card. No matter how far out  of first we are, it keeps us from  getting shut out at our favorite  hotels and restaurants.
So if you're looking for some big  league clout, apply for the little  green home run hitter.
Look what it's done for us. People  still don't recognize us, but... (whispering) ...we're in the first division now.
sliding across home plate in his tuxedo and stopping IN F He holds up an American Express card in a black-gloved ha
The American Express card. Don't  steal home without it.
filing into Cleveland Municipal Stadium. Tickets being ri programs sold, etc.
swinging and hitting a home run into the left field seats
beating the tom-toms and whooping it up. The SHOT WIDENS reveal they're no longer alone in the stands.
nailing up another pair of gloves above his head. There a a lot of them up there now.
On the road again. Everyone's asleep except Taylor who li across his seat, heating pads on his knees.
watching TV in a Cleveland working-class bar. Also cheeri the Indians are several punk and heavy metal kids, their  faces painted with Indian war paint. Strange bedfellows.
hitting a prodigious home run onto the roof.
standing up to cheer Cerrano's homer, then remembering he with Rachel. He sits down apologetically. Rachel watches events on the field with a face of cold steel.

hitting a double into the right centerfield alley with tw runners on. Hayes, the trailing runner, catches up with the lead runn and they reach the plate at about the same time, one slid around the Catcher one way, one around the other. Both score as the Catcher tries to tag both and gets neit
going wild, while the Indian mascot dances on top of the  dugout.
The program in progress is suddenly interrupted by a Spor Break logo appearing on the screen.
We interrupt this program to bring  you the following special bulletin.
live outside the Indian's locker room. He wears a headdre warpaint, and a Wild Thing T-shirt.

Good evening, everybody. The  incredible has happened. The Indians  have finished the regular season in  a first place tie with the New York  Yankees on the strength of a 4-2 win  over the Tigers in Detroit today.  There will be a one-game playoff  here in Cleveland the day after  tomorrow to decide the Eastern  Division Championship, the Indians  having won the coin flip held just  moments ago in the American League  office. We'll have further details  on the news at 11, but for now, get  your tomahawks ready, Cleveland.

head_text.subj: A PIECE OF LEOPARD SKIN FABRIC

text: We hear cheers as it's ripped away to reveal the photogra image of Rachel's cleavage. We PULL BACK to see the life- size poster is now completely peeled. Rachel stares out a us in a G-string and tassels. The photo is obviously from her showgirl days. General merriment prevails in the locker room. Players sh hands, back slapping, etc. Hayes comes by to exchange  congratulations with Taylor. MUSIC and MONTAGE END.
Hey, not bad for a has-been and a  never-will-be.
We haven't won anything yet. We still  got one more to go.
Dorn comes by Taylor's locker.
Hey, Taylor, there's a coupla drop- dead Annies outside. One of 'em says  she used to know you pretty good.  Brunette, great rack...
Darla.
Yeh. What doya say we chat 'em up?
(without much  enthusiasm) I don't know...
C'mon, you're not gonna keep moonin'  over that library chick, are you?  Forget her, she's gone.
We leave Taylor thinking it over.
Suzanne Dorn is watching the 11 o'clock news. HAL CHARLES holding forth.

The Indians are spending the night  in Detroit and will bus back to  Cleveland in the morning. We're going  to go back now to Ross Farmer who's  standing by at the Hotel Stanley  where the Indians are staying in  Detroit. Ross?
The scene shifts to...

head_text.subj: THE LOBBY OF THE STANLEY HOTEL

text: where Ross Farmer stands, microphone in hand. Behind him  several players can be seen partying in the bar.
Thank you, Hal. As you can see, the  Indians are in high spirits tonight,  looking forward to their showdown  with the Yankees. Who will start  that game is still a matter of some  conjecture.

As Ross talks, Dorn walks INTO THE FRAME in the far backg with his arm around a YOUNG LOVELY. They're nuzzling and  hugging, unaware they're on camera, albeit in the backgro Suzanne doesn't miss it though. She moves closer to the s to get a better look. Dorn and the Girl get in an elevator together, obviously  going upstairs. As the elevator closes, Suzanne hits the button. She sits there a second in shock, and then her fa begins to harden.
Taylor and DARLA are undressing, preparatory to getting i bed. They are definitely no strangers to each other.
You still got that black Corvette?  The one that the sound system took  up the whole trunk?
No, I had to sell it.
I thought they gave them to ya.
Not after your knees go bad.
That's all right, you'll be gettin'  a new one now.
Darla is down to her bra and panties. She puts her leg up the bed to unhook her stockings. Taylor is about to take his pants, but stops.
Darla, I don't think I can do this.
What do you mean? We did this between  innings once.
I guess I'm just not that guy anymore.
Darla looks at him a long beat.
(resigned) Happens to the best of them sooner  or later. What's her name?
The door opens and Darla comes out, fully clothed now. Sh turns to say goodbye to Jake, who is still bare-chested.
So long, Jake. Too bad. I was gonna  devote a whole chapter to you in my  book.
As Darla gives Jake a goodbye peck, the elevator door ope across the hall, and out steps Lynn. She's obviously ratt by the sight of Taylor and Darla together.
Excuse me. I was in town for a  conference and thought I'd drop by,  but I can see you're busy...
With that she quickly steps back into the elevator and th doors close.
Lynn, wait...
Taylor leaps to the elevator door, but it's too late. He  then sprints to the end of the hall and down the stairs.
running down the stairs and into the lobby. Seeing no sig of Lynn, he races out the front door to see her pulling o in a taxi. He can only stand and watch her disappear into the night.
We PICK UP Vaughn making his way to the back of the bus,  where Brown has his "office" on the last seat. Most of th other players are asleep after a late night of partying.
You wanted to see me?
Yeh, Rick. I just wanted to tell you  that I'm startin' Harris tomorrow  against the Yankees, even though  it's your turn in the rotation.
Vaughn says nothing, but he's clearly disappointed.
He's got more experience and a little  better record against the Yankees.
Yeh, sure. Whatever's best for the  team.
Don't read anything into it, Rick.  You're one of the guys that got us  here.
Yeh, okay.
Vaughn turns and walks back up the aisle. Brown watches h go, knowing he's still upset.
The Indian bus pulls up outside the Stadium, where a grou of several thousand fans wait. The players are showered w cheers and applause as they file out.
Vaughn sits in the bar alone, nursing a beer, still troub by his demotion. He hears a sexy VOICE behind him.
You mind if I join you?
Vaughn turns around to see Suzanne Dorn. She's dressed to draw blood, looking better than we've ever seen her. She  slides into the booth.
I don't think I'd be very good company  tonight.
Why not?
Nothin'. Job problem.
Vaughn falls silent. Suzanne stares at him with a devasta combination of sexual heat and tender admiration. She's  pulling out all the stops. Vaughn's a little flustered.
I'm, ah, a ball player.
I know, but that's not why I came  over. I don't chase ball players.
Why did you come over then?
Because you're the sexiest man I've  ever laid eyes on, and you look like  you could use a... friend.
We GO TO Vaughn. Forget it. He's a goner.
Vaughn has dozed off in the bed. Suzanne, is getting dres Vaughn wakes up as she finishes.
Where you goin'?
I've gotta get home.
I didn't even get your name.
Suzanne. Suzanne Dorn
(having heard that  name someplace before) Suzanne Dorn?
Mrs. Suzanne Dorn. (kissing him on the  forehead) So long. You're a great kid.
With that she walks on out, leaving Vaughn dazed by the  knowledge of who he's just slept with.
Taylor is coming back from the bathroom down the hall as  Suzanne comes out of Vaughn's room.
(nonchalant) Hello, Jake.
Hello, Suzanne.
Taylor is amazed by what he's just seen. As soon as Suzan is out of sight, he goes to Vaughn's room and opens the d
Vaughn?
Vaughn is sitting on his bed in a state of disbelief.
I swear to God I didn't know who she  was.
Taylor nods that it's all right even though he doesn't be it.
Sequence omitted from original script.

pulling up outside the church. Lynn is helped out of the by her Father. As she starts up the steps, she sees that  both sides are lined by the entire Cleveland Indians team uniform. They form an arch of bats as she passes. At the of the steps is Taylor. Lynn stops as her father ushers h mother on into the church.
You look beautiful.
Thank you. I didn't think you'd come.
I can't stay. (indicating the team) We gotta get to the park.
Good luck today, Jake.
Yeh, you too. (pause) Tell me one thing. The night you  came up to my hotel -- was there  really a library conference?
No, I came to see you.
Too bad it didn't work out better. I  just wanna say I'm sorry for all the  things I've put you through over the  years.
Even for last night?
Can't be sorry for that. Nothing  happened.
He says this with absolute conviction. Despite herself, L senses that he's telling the truth.
Then you weren't defending my honor  again?
I didn't have to. She knew she was  outclassed.
Lynn smiles. He gives her a kiss and watches as she goes  inside. He stands there a long beat, then turns and walks slowly down the steps past his teammates.
Rachel is looking out at the empty stadium. There's a KNO at the door.
Come in.
The door is opened by a Male Secretary and in steps Lou B
Hello, Lou, what can I do for ya?
Lou puts a folded piece of paper on her desk.
I wanted to hand in my resignation  before you had a chance to fire me.
What do you mean?
I know what you been tryin' to do  with this team. After the season, I  want no part of it.
Well, I knew I could count on Charlie  to tell somebody. I was just afraid  he might take too long.
Why would you want him to tell  somebody?
So you'd tell the team, hopefully  getting them mad enough to knock  themselves out trying to prove they  belonged in this league. I think it  worked.
You tryin' to make me believe you  wanted us to win all along?
Rachel nods.
Bullshit. What about the plane, the  bus, the bad hotels...

We were broke. We couldn't afford  anything better. Donald left the  team nearly bankrupt. If we'd had  another losing season, I would have  had to sell the team. I knew we  couldn't win with the team we had,  so I decided to bring in new players  and see how they'd do with the proper  motivation. There was never any offer  from Miami. I made it all up.
Why should I believe any of this?  Now that we're winnin' it's easy for  you to jump on the bandwagon.
If I'd really wanted you to lose,  all I had to do was send the best  players back to the minors. But I  didn't, did I?
Brown has no comeback for this. He knows now that she's  telling the truth.

You think this was all an accident?  I personally scouted every member of  this team, except Hayes, of course.  He was a surprise. They all had flaws  which concealed their real talent,  or I wouldn't have been able to get  them. But I knew if anyone could  straighten them out, you could. And  if you tell them any of this, I will  fire you.
Brown can only shake his head at this whole thing.
I love this team, Lou. Go get 'em  tonight.
The two shake hands. Brown looks at Rachel a beat, still  looking for some sign of duplicity. Finally he gives her grudging smile of respect.
Taylor, Hayes, Vaughn and the others are getting ready to board the bus to the stadium. Taylor pulls Vaughn aside.
I don't know what Dorn's wife is up  to, but I think it'd be best if you  dressed early and got out to the  bullpen before Dorn comes in.
Vaughn nods.
(to Taylor) We got a problem. Cerrano wants some  extra power for tonight. He's lookin'  to sacrifice a live chicken. We can't  have people pukin' in the locker  room before the game.
Tell him not to worry, I'll take  care of it.
Dorn is ready to leave for the park.
Bye bye, honey, wish me luck.
Before you go, there's something I  wanta tell you.
Uh oh, we know what this is all about.

The place is jammed. 75,000 screaming maniacs, most of th decked out in war paint and head dresses. Some carry plas scalps with Yankee hats on them. Others have caps with th European "No" insignia superimposed over a door mat.
In the press box.
Here's your bourbon.
Won't need it tonight.
starkly quiet in contrast to the stadium outside. Each pl has retreated into his own world of concentration. Dorn approaches Taylor, who's fitting heavy athletic brac on both knees.
You know where Vaughn is?
Nope. Haven't seen him.
Let me know if you do. I wanna have  a little talk with him.
Dorn moves off.
Where's my chicken?
It's comin' in now.
We see a Bat Boy enter with a bucket of fried chicken. Ce looks at it in bewilderment.
One whole chicken, like you said.
But it no alive.
Believe me, Jo-Buu will like this.  He's gotta be gettin' tired of raw  chicken.
As Cerrano hefts the bucket somewhat skeptically and take it to his altar, we...
warming up in the bullpen. The tension of starting such a important game shows in his face.

Hello, everybody, Harry Doyle bidding  you a Wahoo welcome from beautiful  Municipal Stadium, where tonight  before a capacity crowd of 75,000  screaming featherheads, the braves  of the Cuyahoga will leave their  teepees in search of Cleveland's  first League Championship in over 30  years. Standing in the way, their  long time nemesis, the New York  Yankees, the Big Boys of Broadway,  who have beaten the Indians like a  tom-tom all year long.
Down in the dugout, the players are lined up ready to tak the field. They exchange words of encouragement, hand sla clenched fists, but all at a very low key level. This is  tension time.
All right, guys, let's take it to  'em.

The Indians charge onto the field to a standing ovation. In the center field bleachers Thelma's victory blanket  containing the scores of every Indian game for the season hangs from a railing. Bobby, Vic and Johnny pound the tom toms leading the stadium in a monster version of "In the  Land of Burning Waters." Even the groundskeepers join in. Two down in the first. Harris looking sharp so far... Bou ball to third. Dorn up with it.
Throwing the first pitch. The YANKEE HITTER grounds one t Dorn who throws him out.
0-0 in the 3rd.
striking out on a curve ball.
robbing a Yankee of a home run by making a leaping catch  over the fence.
picking a Yankee runner off first.
0-0 in the 5th.
Sequence omitted from original script.
striking out on a curve ball, trying to check his swing.  Umpire emphatically punches him out.
Looking past him to the field. Harris is on the mound. Th a runner on second.
Still nothing -- nothing, top of the  seventh, two down. Harris has been  in trouble all night, but has battled  his way out with the help of some  great defensive plays.
Harris comes set and delivers. The Yankee hitter, BURTON, (L) swings and gets all of it.
Uh oh, this one's tagged. Deep center  field. Way back. Way back.
Hayes climbs up on the wall, but it's long gone. Home run
It's off the reservation, home run.  And the Yankees lead it 2-0.
Shit.
Donovan is a little confused by this. Burton trots around the bases and is greeted by jubilant  teammates at the plate. A silent pall falls on the stadiu As the "2" goes up on the scoreboard, we...
popping up and flinging his bat away in frustration. We t CUTS of the worried fans, chewing fingernails, wadding up programs, hanging their heads, etc.
grounding out, obviously having trouble running. We take  CUTS of worried faces on the bench.
stepping into the batter's box. The crowd is practically  sitting on its hands now. Hope draining away.
Dorn up now, two down, bottom of the  seventh. The Indians running out of  chances.
Dorn swings at the first pitch and lines a sharp single t left. The crowd and the Indian bench suddenly come alive. Cerrano moves to the plate.
That'll bring on Cerrano, hitless  tonight. As a matter of fact, he  hasn't touched the ball yet.

The crowd and bleacher band begins to clap as Dorn takes lead. Cerrano swings at the first pitch and misses. An au groan goes through the crowd. The Yankee pitcher gets set again, and throws Cerrano a b roundhouse curve. He misses it a foot. Strike two.
Damn, havin' trouble with the curve  ball again.
We should've gotten him a live  chicken.
Cerrano steps out and begins to talk to his bat, gesturin and pointing as if arguing with his wife.
I pissed off now, Jo-Buu. I good to  you, I stand up for you. If you no  help me now, I say fuck you, Jo-Buu.  I do it myself.

Cerrano gets back in the box and digs in. The Yankee pitc comes to his stretch and delivers. Another big breaking c ball. Cerrano swings and knocks the crap out of it. Every in the stands and on the bench jumps to their feet, rooti for the ball to get out.
Long drive, deep centerfield. Way  back. It might be. It could be. The  ball is... Downtown, welcome to the  Happy Hunting Ground. The game is  tied.
The fans go crazy as Cerrano circles the bases.

Rachel jumps out of her seat, hands above her head. Donov hesitates a beat, then follows suit. Cerrano carries his bat with him, holding it high above h head. As Cerrano disappears into the dugout, we go to the scoreboard as the 2 goes up.
Two down in the top of the ninth,  still tied at 2, Harris working on  an eight-hitter.
lining a single to right field. Harris mops his brow,  obviously tiring.
smashing a double off the wall, the lead runner stopping third. Brown signals to the bullpen to get somebody warm.
on the mound, looking like he's out of gas.
Activity continues in the pen, as  Harris is really digging himself a  hole now. He got the first two  hitters, and then gave up a single  and a double and has now gone 3-0 to  Cheevers.
Harris comes set and fires to the plate. It's way high.
High, ball four and they're loaded  for Haywood, the biggest Indian killer  of them all.
Brown has seen enough. He makes his way to the mound.
(taking the ball from  Harris) You pitched a hell of a game, Steve.  Take a seat and we'll see if we can  get this guy for ya.
Brown signals to the bullpen with his left hand.
Give me Vaughn.
(surprised) You want Vaughn?
I know he hasn't done real well  against this guy, but I got a hunch  he's due.

striding in from the bullpen. He doesn't look relaxed. As nears the infield he purposely doesn't look at Dorn. Dorn stares at him with undisguised venom. As Vaughan gets to the mound, he sees Patton getting his  convict uniform on in the Yankee dugout. He looks away to see Haywood in the on-deck circle smiling out at him. Meanwhile, the CROWD has gone nuts at the sight of Vaughn Bobby, Vic and Johnny are blasting out "Wild Thing" on th tom-toms and the whole stadium, 75,000 strong, is singing it. Doyle just pushes the mic forward and lets the crowd it's work.
Okay, Ricky, Haywood likes the hard  stuff in. Curve him on the hands,  bust him away, and don't get up with  anything. You listenin' to me Rick?
Vaughn nods, but we can tell he's too nervous to have dig any of that.
(Patting him on the  butt) O.K., kid, you're my man. Let's go  get him.
C'mon Ricky, this guy is the out you  been waitin' your whole life for.
Brown and Taylor leave Vaughn alone on the mound, the SIN of the crowd ringing in his ears.
O.K. Vaughn has finished his warmup  and we're ready to...
No sooner has Taylor settled in behind the plate, than Do starts toward the mound. Vaughn watches him come with fea and trepidation.
(seeing it) Oh, shit.
Dorn arrives at the mound, and holds out his hand for the ball. Vaughn gives it to him. Dorn rubs it up, staring lo and hard into Vaughn's eyes. Vaughn is sweating bullets.  Finally Dorn speaks.
Let's cut through the crap. I only  got one thing to say to you. Just  rear back and strike this motherfucker  out.

He smiles and hands Vaughn the ball back. Vaughn returns smile and accepts the ball. While Dorn trots back to his  position, Vaughn turns his back to the plate for one last moment of concentration. As he turns around to face us, w see a new man as the wicked opening CHORDS of X's "Wild T are heard on the TRACK, only louder and more savage than  before. Vaughn steps up on the rubber, his face hardened into fie resolve. There's nothing nervous about him now. This kid gonna make somebody pay.
Haywood steps in, the American League  triple crown winner. .341 average,  48 homers, 121 R.B.I.'s. He's homered  the only two times he's faced Vaughn.

Taylor sets down a sign. Two fingers for the curve ball.  Vaughn shakes it off. Taylor puts down another sign. Vaug shakes it off. Finally, Taylor puts down one finger -- th fast ball. Vaughn nods with steely purpose.
All right, Ricky, let's get nasty.

Vaughn winds and delivers a hissing blur toward the plate Haywood takes a ferocious swing and misses. Strike one. We see the number 97 come up on the digital readout of th SPEED GUN which a club employee holds behind the screen.
(to Haywood) All right, looks like the boy is  pumped. Sucker was movin', wasn't  it? Ever hit ya, it'd leave a two  foot hole comin' out.
Taylor gets ready to flash another sign. The convict jump up and down trying to distract Vaughn. No way.
(for Haywood's ears) Let's see, what should we call now.  Let's see how he feels about old  number one.

Taylor puts down one finger. Vaughn nods and then winds a fires again, another blazing rocket. Haywood takes a wick rip, but doesn't get it. Strike two. 99 comes up on the g The convict has stopped jumpin'.
Nice swing, Haywood. Good follow- through. Keep it up, I'll show you  the ball sometime.
The fans are going wild. They're all standing now, yellin for a strikeout. Vaughn gets back up on the rubber with t look of an animal sighting prey. Taylor gets down to give the sign.
Forget the curveball. Go with the  heater.
Well, shit, all these pitches to  choose from. Maybe we'll try somethin'  different this time.
Taylor wiggles his fingers around and then puts down the No. 1. Vaughn gives him a quick nod.
And if I don't see you again, Haywood,  have a nice winter. Okay, buddy?

Vaughn goes into his windup and unleashes a screaming bul toward the plate. Haywood pulls the trigger, but it's alr by him. Strike three. 101 on the gun. Taylor leaps up and gives Vaughn the fist. The fans are going berserk. MUSIC  ends.
Oh, Lordy, three straight heaters  and the Yankees are blown down. No  runs, two hits, three left on, and,  are you ready, Cleveland? We go to  the bottom of the ninth, still tied  at two.
Doyle turns the mike off.
(to his color man) Can you believe this, Monty?
Monty takes a big swig straight from the bourbon bottle.

walking up to the plate.
Two down in the ninth, Hayes steps  in hitting .291, trying to get  something going for the Tribe.

Taylor and the others yell encouragement to Hayes as he d in at the plate. The Yankee pitcher delivers and Hayes hi a high bouncer toward short. The shortstop waits for it t come down and then fires to first. Too late. Hayes streak across the bag, beating the throw by a hair. Once again t CROWD comes to life. The Yankee Manager comes to the mound and waves for a new pitcher.
And Horton is wasting no time. He's  goin' to the Duke.
Out of the pen comes BILLY DUKE, a good facsimile of Goos Gossage only Duke is bigger and meaner. (INSERT STORYBOARD #219M)
Duke leads the league in saves,  strikeouts per inning and nose hairs.

The Duke finishes his warmups and stares over at Hayes. H smiles, snaps his black gloves out of his hip pocket, and carefully pulls them on over his hands. The Duke does not care for this kind of showmanship. Brown comes over to talk to Taylor, who's been watching D from the on-deck circle.

Ya know I'd be an ass not to pinch- hit for you here. You're 0 for 18  against Duke. Plus you're beat to  shit you can hardly walk, there's no  way you can get around on this guy's  fast ball. So I want the absolute  truth here. Can you beat this guy?
Yeh.
Okay.
Taylor starts for the plate, as Duke finishes his warmups Brown comes down the dugout steps.
(to Pepper) Send Hayes the first pitch. I don't  want Taylor takin' too many strikes.

Pepper begins flashing signs out to Hayes. Duke gets up o the rubber and takes his stretch. Hayes leads away, crouc low. Duke snaps a throw over to first, the first baseman  slapping a hard tag on Hayes, but Hayes is back. The crowd is on its feet again. The "GO" chant starts,  punctuated by thousands of black-gloved hands punching th night air. Duke comes set again. Hayes leads away. Duke watches him, checks him again. We go to SLOW MOTION as Duke kicks and  comes to the plate. Hayes takes off like a shot, head down, eating up ground. Taylor swings and misses. The Yankee catcher comes up  throwing, rifling a clothesline dart to second base. Haye leaves his feet diving for the bag. The second baseman sn down the tag. Too late. Hayes is in there. The stadium is really rockin' now. Duke prowls the mound. Taylor steps out of the box and flashes a sign to Brown.
What's he doing?
Flashing some signals. That's a hell  of an idea.

Brown flashes a sign out to Hayes. A hint of a smile come over Hayes' face as he dusts himself off. Taylor steps back in as Duke gets up on the rubber. Taylo digs in his back foot, then points to the left field blea ala Babe Ruth.
What's this? Taylor is pointing to  the bleachers, calling his shot.

The crowd, electrified by Taylor's gesture, remains on it feet. Duke stares in at Taylor, comes to his stretch and  then lets go a steaming fast ball right at Taylor's head. Taylor goes down in a swirl of dust, the ball missing him inches. The stadium explodes with BOOS, but as soon as Ta picks himself up, the crowd begins to ROAR again. Bobby, Vic and Johnny are pounding out a heavy beat on th TOM-TOMS. Everyone in the stadium begins to CLAP in uniso with the DRUMS. Taylor steps back in and once again points to the bleache
(Taylor points again) Unbelievable. They're on their feet  here, stomping, clapping. C'mon,  join in wherever you are out there.  Let's hear you, Cleveland.
and several of their friends at their bar, huddled around the RADIO with the punks and heavy metal kids we saw befo Slowly they begin to clap in time with the tom-toms which are audible on the T.V.
at the opera with his wife, a radio earplug in his ear. H hand taps on his leg in sync with the TOM-TOMS.
(Sc 222 before scene 221) beating on their shovels in the bullpen.
FRAMED against the Cleveland skyline. In several of the l windows we see people banging things or clapping.

Duke gets back on the hill. Getting the sign he wants, he comes to his stretch, checking Hayes at second. As Duke starts his delivery to the plate, we go to SLOW  MOTION. The clapping in the stadium stops as everyone hus to watch the pitch. We...

text: They've all stopped too in anticipation of the pitch.

streaking for home, trying to score all the way from seco on a bunt. The first baseman fires to the plate, as the catcher posi himself for the throw. Hayes launches into a flying feet- first slide. The catcher brings the tag down. Hayes hooks the outside, his trailing foot reaching for the plate.
Hayes is gonna try to score! Here  comes the throw. He slides. He is...

...Safe. The Indians win it. The  Indians win. Oh my God, the Indians  win it!!

Pandemonium breaks loose in Municipal Stadium. Rachel hug Donovan, dances around, punches the air, then hugs Donova again. Everywhere people are hugging and kissing each oth Bobby, Vic and Johnny are going berserk in the bleachers. Thelma sits quietly, a tear rolling down her cheek.

of our other fans. We see... A) The Business Executive stand up and yell "Yes!" in the middle of the opera. Several other men stand up and expre their excitement as well. B) The Longshoremen whoop it up in their bar -- exchangin fives and hugs with the punkers and heavy metal kids. C) The various apartment dwellers dancing, clapping, yell out the windows. D) The two Korean Groundskeepers just shaking their heads amazement. E) Elsewhere in the stadium, the joyous exultation contin unabated.
